Award.AwardTitle: NeTS: Small: Collaborative Research: Towards Reliable, Energy-Efficient, and Secure Vehicular Networks

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The general vehicular networking system (VNS), where the vehicular ad hoc network (VANET) is integrated with hybrid electric vehicles (HEVs), enables a wide range of intelligent transportation system (ITS) applications. With different visions on VANETs, most of the existing studies provide case-specific solutions in an incoherent manner, which can hardly be integrated into an effective system. This project aims at developing a reliable, energy-efficient, and secure VNS with a synergetic approach through five complementary research tracks: infrastructure optimization, protocol design for reliable networking performance, energy-efficient VNS, security and privacy provisioning, and virtual-field testbed development. This project is expected to significantly advance the state of the art of VANET research by addressing some fundamental research issues. Analytical models are developed to study the road-side infrastructure deployment, networking protocols and control algorithms for optimal performance, considering the complex issues of mobility, interference, and data traffic dynamics. The throughput-optimal control in a multi-radio multi-channel context with dynamic network topology is studied to improve the throughput over a multi-hop vehicular network. Energy-efficient solutions are pursued by exploiting the interplay between the VNET and HEVs. Scalable security protocols with small computation and communication overhead are developed to provision security and privacy in VANET.

The proposed research seamlessly integrates research and education activities in the areas of optimization, probability and random process, graph theory, wireless networking, HEV technologies, as well as computer simulations. The research proposed in this project has a good potential to be transformed into practical protocols or control algorithms for VANETs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The current transportation system is being reshaped by the emerging technologies of vehicular ad hoc networks (VANETs) and hybrid electric vehicles (HEVs). Such a general vehicular networking system (VNS) enables a wide range of intelligent transportation system (ITS) applications including safety and mobility enhancement, data downloading for entertainment, and energy consumption control. This project has achieved a reliable, energy-efficient, and secure VNS with a synergetic approach, where the complex interplay between different components in the system are addressed in a systematic manner. This collaborative project, between Illinois Institute of Technology and University of North Carolina at Charlotte, has fundamentally advance the state of the art of VANET research from four main aspects.

1)      A set of models and analytical methods have been developed to study the road-side infrastructure deployment, networking protocols and control algorithms for optimal performance, considering the complex issues of mobility, interference, and data traffic dynamics. The study is in an interdisciplinary nature, taking tools from graph theory, optimization, stochastic analysis, social behavior analysis, and machine learning. Effective topology control and routing protocols have been developed to ensure network connectivity and high throughput in a highly dynamic environment.

2)      The medium access control issue in VANET have been studied from the perspectives of both distributed coordination and TDMA based scheduling. Specifically, distributed opportunistic relaying based on random backoff has been proposed and mathematically studied with stochastic geometry.  The TDMA-based scheduling is studied in a general multi-hop multi-radio multi-channel (MR-MC) setting. An original multi-dimensional tuple based model is developed to transform the network into a virtual single-radio single-channel network node. Such a framework facilitates the derivation of throughput-optimal control algorithms in the MR-MC networking context.

3)      The energy efficiency issue in VNS is addressed coherently through network protocol optimization and charging management. The energy efficiency optimization problem involves many coupled factors such as road-side-unites (RSUs) deployment, routing, transmission scheduling, transmit power control, and radio and channel assignment.  Thus, decomposed approaches are developed to solve the energy efficiency optimization problem with low complexity but high accuracy and guaranteed performance. The interplay between electrical vehicles and charging stations are modeled as a multi-leader multi-flower Stackelberg game. New theoretical results on Nash equilibrium and price of anarchy analysis have been contributed.

4)      An efficient on-line key establishment for secure device-to-device communications has been achieved, which plays a fundamentally important role in enabling both inter-vehicle and intro-vehicle secure communications. The on-line key establishment protocol is achieved through an innovative design based on integrity-guaranteed messages and behavior monitorability over a wireless channel.

 

The outcomes from this project have cross-disciplinary impact. Results from this project have led to better understanding of the social dynamics in large-scale vehicular networks and urban dynamic, which can support numerous commercial and civilian applications. In addition, the novel theoretical analysis techniques proposed in this project can also be used in other related area such as graph theory, data mining, mobile computing, and social network analysis.  The modeling of 802.11 based MAC and associated security solutions also benefit the studies on developing security solutions for 802.15.4 based wireless networks, and modeling of a MAC protocol for LTE-U co-existing with Wi-Fi. Motivations of exploiting the computing power of vehicles in a VANET has inspired interdisciplinary studies crossing areas of cloud computing, edge computing, autonomic management, wireless network and information security.

The outcomes from this project have been published in top-tier conference proceedings and journals, disseminated to research communities through invited talks in both academia and industry, and leveraged to enhance graduate courses and design undergraduate research projects. This project has trained highly qualified researchers and engineers for the networking and communications industry, and produced excellent PhD graduates with creativity, dedication, and professionalism. A few students involved in this project have obtained R&D jobs after graduation in InterDigital, Amazon, and Huawei Research US, respectively.
